{{disambig-two|the language of the [[Ents]]|scene from the film ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers]]''|'''[[Old Entish (scene)]]'''}}
[[File:Per Sjögren - The Entmoot.jpg|thumb|''The Entmoot'' by [[:Category:Images by Per Sjögren|Per Sjögren]]]]
{{quote|Real names tell you the story of the things they belong to in my language, in the Old Entish as you might say. It is a lovely language, but it takes a very long time to say anything in it, because we do not say anything in it, unless it
is worth taking a long time to say, and to listen to.|[[Treebeard]] in ''[[The Two Towers]]'', "[[Treebeard (chapter)|Treebeard]]"}}

'''Entish''' or '''Old Entish''' was the slow, sonorous, rumbling and ancient language of the [[Ents]].

In ancient days, after meeting the [[Elves]], the Ents developed the desire for a spoken language. The language that resulted from this desire was unlike any among the other [[races]] of Middle-earth. It was slow, sonorous, agglomerated, repetitive, and extremely long-winded. The lore-masters of the [[Eldar]] made no attempt to represent it in writing, as its many vowel-shades and tonal distinctions were far too numerous to do so.<ref>{{App|Other}}, ''Ents'', p. 1130-1131</ref>

Other examples are limited, with one being ''burárum'',<ref>{{TT|Treebeard}} p. 466, 479</ref><ref name=":0">[[J.R.R. Tolkien]]. [[The Lord of the Rings]], [[The Return of the King]], [[Many Partings]], p. 979</ref> an Entish noise of disgust.<ref>{{PE|17}}, entry E '''burárum''', p. 79</ref> The recording of ''[[a-lalla-lalla-rumba-kamanda-lind-or-burúmë]]'', a part of the name for a ''hill,''<ref>{{TT|Treebeard}}, p. 465</ref> is described as  "the only extant (probably very inaccurate)" fragment of Entish.<ref name=":1">{{App|Other}}, ''Ents'', p. 1131</ref>

==Usage of Elvish among the Ents==
The Ents found [[Quenya]] to be a lovely language and adapted it after their fashion to everyday use, along with its vocabulary to Entish grammatical structure.<ref name=":1" /> The individual words were easily understandable, although they formed lengthy run-on sentences of redundant adjectives. When Treebeard said "''Taurelilómëa-tumbalemorna Tumbaletaurëa Lómëanor"''<ref>{{TT|Treebeard}} p. 467</ref>'','' he wanted to tell [[Meriadoc Brandybuck|Merry]] and [[Peregrin Took|Pippin]] that "there is a black shadow in the deep dales of the forest", however, the literal translation is "Forestmanyshadowed-deepvalleyblack Deepvalleyforested Gloomyland".<ref name=":1" /> Additionally, when Treebeard described the Orcs, he said "evileyed-blackhanded-bowlegged-flinthearted-clawfingered-foulbellied-bloodthirsty," and added some Quenya: ''morimaite-sincahonda'' ("blackhanded" and "flinthearted").<ref name=":0" />
